total_revenue.context: Q1 revenue was $7.19 billion, up 19% sequentially and down 13% year-on-year.

segments.name: Data Center

revenue.context: Revenue of $4.28 billion was up 18% sequentially and up 14% year-on-year.

key_points: Record revenue driven by accelerated computing platform worldwide.
Generative AI driving exponential growth in compute requirements and transitioning to NVIDIA accelerated computing.
Cloud service providers (CSPs) deploying Hopper and Ampere architecture GPUs to meet AI application surge.
Availability of H100 GPUs on platforms like Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud, Oracle Cloud Infrastructure, with AWS upcoming, and GPU-specialized CSPs like CoreWeave and Lambda.
Strong demand from Generative AI pioneers among CSPs.
Consumer Internet companies adopting Generative AI and deep learning-based recommendation systems.
Enterprise demand strong in verticals such as automotive, financial services, healthcare, and telecom.

Examples include BloombergGPT for financial NLP tasks, CCC Intelligent Solutions using AI for repairs, AT&T improving fleet dispatches with AI, Deloitte for logistics and customer service, and Amgen for drug discovery.
Shipping of DGX H100, Hopper generation AI system for on-prem deployments.
Launch of DGX Cloud through partnerships with Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud, and Oracle Cloud Infrastructure.
Introduction of NVIDIA AI Foundations: NeMo, Picasso, BioNeMo for building and deploying custom AI models.
ServiceNow adopting DGX Cloud and NeMo for developing custom large language models.
MLPerf benchmark shows NVIDIA's inference platform delivering performance ahead of industry standards.

Announcement of four major new inference platforms: L4 Tensor Core GPU, L40 for Omniverse and graphics rendering, H100 NVL for large language models, and Grace Hopper Superchip for LLMs and recommendation systems.
Google Cloud adopting L4 inference platform with G2 virtual machines for generative AI and other workloads.
Integration of Triton inference server with Google Kubernetes Engine and Google Cloud's Vertex AI platform.
Strong demand for Mellanox networking platforms for high-performance networking in AI.
Launch of Quantum-2 40 gigabit per second InfiniBand platform and Spectrum-4 400 gigabit per second Ethernet networking platform.
Grace data center CPU sampling with customers, including University of Bristol's new supercomputer based on Grace CPU Superchip.
BlueField-3, Grace, and Grace Hopper Superchips enabling energy-efficient accelerated data centers.

segments.name: Automotive

revenue.context: Revenue of $296 million was up 1% sequentially and up 114% year-on-year.

key_points: Strong year-on-year growth driven by ramp of NVIDIA DRIVE Orin across new energy vehicles (NEVs).
Automotive design win pipeline over the next six years at $14 billion, up from $11 billion a year ago.
Sequential growth moderated as some NEV customers in China adjust production schedules due to slower than expected demand growth.
Partnership with Foxconn to develop automated and autonomous vehicle platforms, providing scale for volume manufacturing.
Deployment of NVIDIA Drive Super Chip in automakers like Volvo, Lockheed Martin, and Jaguar Land Rover.
NVIDIA Drive operating system received safety certification from TÜV SÜD.
Focus on reducing cost and energy consumption while enhancing performance.
Expanded partnership with BYD to extend use of DRIVE Orin to next-generation high-volume Dynasty and Ocean series of vehicles.

segments.name: Gaming

revenue.context: Revenue of $2.24 billion was up 22% sequentially and down 38% year-on-year.

key_points: Sequential growth driven by sales of 40 Series GeForce RTX GPUs for notebooks and desktops.
Gaming and ProViz emerging from channel inventory corrections.
End demand solid, consistent with seasonality, demonstrating resilience against challenging consumer spending backdrop.
Exceptional launch of Ada Lovelace GPU architecture with GeForce RTX 4090 and RTX 4080.
GeForce RTX 40 Series GPUs feature DLSS 3, AI-driven frame generation for faster gameplay.
Third-generation RTX technology has raised the bar for computer graphics and supercharged gaming.
Total number of RTX games and applications now exceeds 350.
Record number of simultaneous users on Steam, reaching 30 million.
Activision's Call of Duty Modern Warfare 2 set a franchise record with over $800 million in opening weekend sales.
Expansion of GeForce NOW cloud gaming service with over 1,400 games and availability on new gaming devices like Logitech Cloud handheld, cloud gaming Chromebooks, and Razor 5G Edge.
Partnership with Microsoft to bring Xbox PC games to GeForce NOW, starting with Gears 5.

segments.name: ProViz

revenue.context: Revenue of $295 million was up 31% sequentially and down 53% year-on-year.

key_points: Sequential growth driven by stronger workstation demand across mobile and desktop, with strengths in Public Sector, Healthcare, and Automotive.
Year-on-year decline due to channel inventory correction, expected to end in the first half of the year.
Interest in NVIDIA Omniverse continues to build with almost 300,000 downloads and 185 connectors to third-party design applications.

Release of Omniverse features and enhancements, including support for 4K, real-time path tracing, Omniverse Search for AI-powered search through large untagged 3D databases, and Omniverse cloud containers for AWS.
Launch of NVIDIA Omniverse Cloud Services enabling design, publishing, and operation of metaverse applications from anywhere on any device.
Adoption of Omniverse Cloud Services by major companies like Lowe's, Charter Communications, and Deutsche Bahn.
Generative AI as a major new workload for NVIDIA-powered workstations.
Collaboration with Microsoft to transform Windows into a platform for creators and designers with generative AI.
Launch of Omniverse Computing System (OVS) reference designs featuring the new L4 GPU based on the ADA Lovelace architecture.
Expansion of AI software and services offerings with NVIDIA and BioNeMo large language model services.

segments.name: Mellanox
key_points: Mellanox revenue included within Data Center segment; no separate breakdown provided.

segments.name: Computing Products
key_points: No specific data provided for Q1.

segments.name: Auto and ProViz
key_points: No specific data provided for Q1.

segments.name: OEM
key_points: No specific data provided for Q1.

gross_margin.context: GAAP gross margins were 64.6%, and non-GAAP gross margins were 66.8%. Gross margins have largely recovered to prior peak levels, absorbing higher costs and offset by delivering higher valued products and more software.

cash_flow.context: No specific cash flow data provided.

geforce_now_users.context: GeForce NOW registered members now exceed 25 million.

gfnow_games.context: GeForce NOW library now includes over 1,400 games after adding 85 more titles this quarter.

share_repurchases.context: Returned $99 million to shareholders in the form of cash dividends.

share_repurchase_authorization_remaining.context: At the end of Q1, approximately $7 billion remaining under share repurchase authorization through December 2023.

q2_fiscal_2024_revenue.context: Total revenue expected to be $11 billion, plus or minus 2%.

q2_fiscal_2024_gross_margin.context: GAAP and non-GAAP gross margins expected to be 68.6% and 70%, respectively, plus or minus 50 basis points.

q2_fiscal_2024_operating_expenses.context: GAAP operating expenses expected to be approximately $2.71 billion. Non-GAAP operating expenses expected to be approximately $1.9 billion.

q2_fiscal_2024_other_income_expenses.context: GAAP and non-GAAP other income and expenses expected to be an income of approximately $90 million, excluding gains and losses from non-affiliated investments.

q2_fiscal_2024_tax_rates.context: GAAP and non-GAAP tax rates expected to be 14%, plus or minus 1%, excluding any discrete items.

capital_expenditures.context: Capital expenditures expected to be approximately $300 million to $350 million.

full_year_non_gaap_opex_growth.context: Full year non-GAAP OpEx is expected to grow over 30%.

strategic_initiatives: Implemented pricing adjustment programs with Gaming channel partners in response to declining Gaming revenue.
Preparation for new architecture launch in Gaming segment.
Partnership with Siemens to enable AI-powered digital twins on NVIDIA Omniverse.
Advancements to metaverse foundational technologies, including Omniverse Avatar Cloud Engine and new Omniverse connectors.
Release of SDKs for neural graphics to automate creation of virtual worlds.
Rollout plans for new vehicles from OEM partners: NIO, Li Auto, JIDU, Human Horizons, and Pony.ai’s self-driving trucks and robotaxis.
Production of Hopper architecture flagship H100 data center GPU and Grace CPU.
Adoption of Grace CPU Superchip and Grace Hopper Superchip by top computer makers like Dell, HPE, Inspur, Lenovo, and Supermicro.
Focus on AI and large language models with updates to NeMo Megatron framework.
Expansion of GeForce NOW library with over 1,400 games.
Ongoing share repurchase program with nearly $12 billion remaining under authorization through December 2023.
Collaboration with Microsoft to build an advanced cloud-based AI supercomputer.
Launch of NVIDIA Omniverse Computing System (OVS) reference designs featuring the new L4 GPU based on the ADA Lovelace architecture.
Expansion of AI software and services offerings with NVIDIA and BioNeMo large language model services.
Introduction of NVIDIA DGX Cloud offering through Oracle Cloud Infrastructure and Microsoft Azure, Google GCP.
Partnership with Deutsche Bank to accelerate use of AI and machine learning in financial services.
Partnership with Foxconn to develop automated and autonomous vehicle platforms.
Safety certification for NVIDIA Drive operating system from TÜV SÜD.
Launch of NVIDIA Omniverse Cloud Services enabling metaverse applications.
Adoption of Omniverse Cloud Services by major companies like Lowe's, Charter Communications, and Deutsche Bahn.
Launch of NVIDIA AI Foundations: NeMo, Picasso, BioNeMo for building and deploying custom AI models.
Deployment of NVIDIA Drive Super Chip in automakers like Volvo, Lockheed Martin, and Jaguar Land Rover.
Introduction of new inference platforms: L4 Tensor Core GPU, L40 for Omniverse and graphics rendering, H100 NVL for large language models, and Grace Hopper Superchip.

market_opportunities.gaming_growth: Despite short-term challenges, long-term fundamentals in Gaming remain strong with NVIDIA RTX supported by nearly 300 games and applications.

market_opportunities.cloud_gaming_expansion: GeForce NOW registered members exceeding 25 million and expansion of the game library to over 1,400 titles.

market_opportunities.cryptocurrency_mining: Introduction of programs to adjust pricing and position GPUs in response to diminishing contribution from cryptocurrency mining.

market_opportunities.accelerated_computing: AI and accelerated computing driving Data Center growth with strong adoption of A100 and H100 GPUs, Grace CPU, and Spectrum-4 networking platform.

partnerships: Partnership with Siemens to enable AI-powered digital twins on NVIDIA Omniverse.
Collaboration with Microsoft to build an advanced cloud-based AI supercomputer.
Partnerships with Amazon Web Services, Google Cloud, Microsoft Azure, and Oracle Cloud Infrastructure for H-100 based cloud instances.
Partnership with Deutsche Bank to accelerate use of AI and machine learning in financial services.
Partnership with Foxconn to develop automated and autonomous vehicle platforms.

technological_advancements: Advancements to metaverse foundational technologies, including Omniverse Avatar Cloud Engine and new Omniverse connectors.
Release of SDKs for neural graphics to automate creation of virtual worlds.
Update to NeMo Megatron framework to speed up training of large language models by up to 30%.
Launch of NVIDIA Omniverse Computing System (OVS) reference designs featuring the new L4 GPU based on the ADA Lovelace architecture.

customer_adoption: Adoption of Grace CPU Superchip and Grace Hopper Superchip by top computer makers like Dell, HPE, Inspur, Lenovo, and Supermicro.
72% of the systems on the latest top 500 list of the world’s fastest supercomputers are powered by NVIDIA.
NVIDIA’s Selene supercomputer ranks at number 8 in the top 500 and is the world’s fastest enterprise supercomputer.
23 of the top 30 systems on the Green 500 list of the most energy-efficient supercomputers are powered by NVIDIA.
Adoption of Omniverse Cloud Services by major companies like Lowe's, Charter Communications, and Deutsche Bahn.
Deployment of NVIDIA Drive Super Chip in automakers like Volvo, Lockheed Martin, and Jaguar Land Rover.
Adoption of H100 data center GPU by Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud, Amazon Web Services, and Oracle Cloud Infrastructure.

introduction: Q1 revenue was $7.19 billion, up 19% sequentially and down 13% year-on-year.
Strong sequential growth driven by record data center revenue, with gaming and professional visualization platforms emerging from channel inventory corrections.
gaming: Revenue of $2.24 billion was up 22% sequentially and down 38% year-on-year.
Fiscal year revenue of $9.07 billion is down 27%.
Sequential growth driven by sales of 40 Series GeForce RTX GPUs for both notebooks and desktops.
End demand was solid and consistent with seasonality, demonstrating resilience against a challenging consumer spending backdrop.
Exceptional launch of new Ada Lovelace GPU architecture with GeForce RTX 4090 and RTX 4080.
GeForce RTX 40 Series GPUs feature DLSS 3, AI-driven frame generation for faster gameplay.
Third-generation RTX technology has raised the bar for computer graphics and supercharged gaming.
Total number of RTX games and applications now exceeds 350.
Record number of simultaneous users on Steam, reaching 30 million.
Activision's Call of Duty Modern Warfare 2 set a franchise record with over $800 million in opening weekend sales.
Expansion of GeForce NOW cloud gaming service with over 1,400 games and availability on new gaming devices like Logitech Cloud handheld, cloud gaming Chromebooks, and Razor 5G Edge.
Partnership with Microsoft to bring Xbox PC games to GeForce NOW, starting with Gears 5.
proviz: Revenue of $295 million was up 31% sequentially and down 53% year-on-year.
Sequential growth driven by stronger workstation demand across mobile and desktop form factors, with strengths in key verticals such as Public Sector, Healthcare, and Automotive.
Year-on-year decline reflects impact of channel inventory correction, expected to end in the first half of the year.
Interest in NVIDIA Omniverse continues to build with almost 300,000 downloads and 185 connectors to third-party design applications.

Release of Omniverse features and enhancements, including support for 4K, real-time path tracing, Omniverse Search for AI-powered search through large untagged 3D databases, and Omniverse cloud containers for AWS.
Launch of NVIDIA Omniverse Cloud Services enabling design, publishing, and operation of metaverse applications from anywhere on any device.
Adoption of Omniverse Cloud Services by major companies like Lowe's, Charter Communications, and Deutsche Bahn.
Generative AI is a major new workload for NVIDIA-powered workstations.
Collaboration with Microsoft to transform Windows into the ideal platform for creators and designers with generative AI.
Launch of Omniverse Computing System (OVS) reference designs featuring the new L4 GPU based on the ADA Lovelace architecture.
Expansion of AI software and services offerings with NVIDIA and BioNeMo large language model services.
automotive: Revenue of $296 million, up 1% sequentially and up 114% year-on-year.
Strong year-on-year growth driven by ramp of NVIDIA DRIVE Orin across a number of new energy vehicles (NEVs).
Automotive design win pipeline over the next six years now stands at $14 billion, up from $11 billion a year ago.
Sequential growth moderated as some NEV customers in China are adjusting production schedules to reflect slower than expected demand growth.
Expanded partnership with Foxconn to develop automated and autonomous vehicle platforms, providing scale for volume manufacturing.
Deployment of NVIDIA Drive Super Chip in automakers like Volvo, Lockheed Martin, and Jaguar Land Rover.
NVIDIA Drive operating system received safety certification from TÜV SÜD.
Focus on reducing cost and energy consumption while enhancing performance.
data_center: Revenue of $4.28 billion was up 18% sequentially and up 14% year-on-year.
Fiscal year revenue was $15 billion, up 41%.
Hyperscale customer revenue posted strong sequential growth, though short of expectations as some CSPs paused at the end of the year to recalibrate build plans.
Tightening reflects overall macroeconomic uncertainty, believed to be a timing issue as end market demand for GPUs and AI infrastructure is strong.
Networking grew a bit less than expected due to softer demand for general purpose CPU infrastructure.
Total data center sequential revenue decline driven by lower sales in China, reflecting COVID and other domestic issues.
Serving an expanding list of fast-growing cloud service providers, including Oracle and GPU-specialized CSPs.
Revenue growth from CSP customers last year significantly outpaced Data Center as a whole as more enterprise customers moved to a cloud-first approach.
On a trailing 4-quarter basis, CSP customers drove about 40% of Data Center revenue.
Adoption of new flagship H100 data center GPU is strong, with H100 revenue much higher than A100, which declined sequentially.
H100 offers 9x faster performance for training and 30x faster for inference in transformer-based large language models.
LLM adoption is at an inflection point with ChatGPT capturing interest worldwide.
Generative AI applications improving productivity across various tasks.
Generative large language models with over 100 billion parameters are the most advanced neural networks.
Working with industry leaders in large language models.
Announced partnership with Deutsche Bank to accelerate use of AI and machine learning in financial services.
Captured leading results for AI inference in key financial services industry benchmark.
Networking growth driven by latest generation InfiniBand and HPC optimized Ethernet platforms fueled by AI.
Generative AI foundation model sizes continue to grow, driving need for high-performance networking.
Launch of Quantum-2 40 gigabit per second InfiniBand platform.
Launch of Spectrum-4 400 gigabit per second Ethernet networking platform.
Expansion of NVIDIA AI enterprise software offerings.
